subject: Discoverable Ironic Drivers
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:24:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:49:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This is a great idea, but I think we should have a wrapper workflow in tripleo-common. The problem is that the set of drivers and their properties that we support comes from both ironic itself AND enrollment logic in tripleo-common. Ironic knows which drivers are enabled, but tripleo-common knows which drivers we can use. Ditto for driver properties: we have this logic there.

Bonus: I will be more actively reviewing python/mistral code than JS :)'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-03-19 16:02:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dmitry:

This patch is about what we allow the end user to configure, with an eye towards fully supporting the list of drivers that we configure in our Undercloud. Currently the UI hard codes 2 drivers for IPMI and DRAC. Dynamically discovering the drivers (from Ironic) and only displaying the ones that both it supports and the UI supports is the only way to do this I think.

As for Mistral workflows... yes they will have a part here too but I think that those workflows should always support configuring all of the drivers (as many as we can support anyways). The workflows are a 'man in the middle' of sorts. They do not control the enablement of drivers in Ironic which is handled by ironic.conf and python. Yes, all these things need to align but I'm not sure I agree that modeling the UI around a workflow to register nodes is the best approach. In short:

1) Our Mistral workflow should support registering nodes against all driver types.
2) The UI should dynamically discover the enabled drivers (this patch!)
3) The user can enable or disable the drivers as they please when they choose to install their Undercloud.

If we do these things we are on the right track I think to fully support hardware registration needs ATM."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-03-19 16:18:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Dynamically discovering the drivers (from Ironic) and only displaying the ones that both it supports and the UI supports is the only way to do this I think.

The issue is in "from Ironic". Ironic is not the only entity in TripleO that tells you what you can enroll and how. This is why we should go through workflows to achieve the same.

> I think that those workflows should always support configuring all of the drivers

They should, but they do not. I'm not sure if anybody is working on fixing it, and I'm not sure it can be done without breaking changes. It's at the very least quite non-trivial.'}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-03-19 16:27:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

dprince, you can fix code-formatting issues with "npm run prettier", and then of course there is "npm run lint" to check for other errors.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-03-20 23:20:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-03-20 23:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-03-21 10:17:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Looks pretty good, a couple of notes inline. Also It may be worth considering renaming Drivers to IronicDrivers so it is more explicit but it may very well be YAGNI.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-03-21 10:20:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-03-21 11:26:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-03-21 12:19:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-12-29 13:48:09.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This patch has no activity for a while, per policy, we abandon it. Feel free to re-open if you think you're working on it."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-19 15:24:54.000000000', 'message': 'Discoverable Ironic Drivers

Change-Id: Ic5693506e67ca1a54ba88bdb4e6a02be0ebe4644
WIP: kind of working... still need to add forms
'}, {'created': '2018-03-20 23:20:29.000000000', 'message': 'Discoverable Ironic Drivers

This patch wires in the ability to discover which drivers are active
in Ironic (via query to /drivers) and only displays the ability to
configure drivers which are currently enabled in Ironic.

Three extra driverFields were also added in this patch. (These are
currently static so that we can easily support language customizations
for the UI). The new additions include Ilo, Redfish, and Iboot.
With the additions of Ilo and Redfish the UI would now support the
same stock settings as our Undercloud with support for Ilo, Redfish,
IPMI, and DRAC.

Co-Authored-By: Jiri Tomasek <jtomasek@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Honza Pokorny <honza@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic5693506e67ca1a54ba88bdb4e6a02be0ebe4644
'}, {'created': '2018-03-20 23:24:25.000000000', 'message': 'Discoverable Ironic Drivers

This patch wires in the ability to discover which drivers are active
in Ironic (via query to /drivers) and only displays the ability to

Three extra driverFields were also added in this patch. (These are
currently static so that we can easily support language customizations
for the UI). The new additions include Ilo, Redfish, and Iboot.
With the additions of Ilo and Redfish the UI would now support the
same stock settings as our Undercloud with support for Ilo, Redfish,
IPMI, and DRAC.

commit_message:
Discoverable Ironic Drivers

This patch wires in the ability to discover which drivers are active
in Ironic (via query to /drivers) and only displays the ability to
configure drivers which are currently enabled in Ironic.

Three extra driverFields were also added in this patch. (These are
currently static so that we can easily support language customizations
for the UI). The new additions include Ilo, Redfish, and Iboot.
With the additions of Ilo and Redfish the UI would now support the
same stock settings as our Undercloud with support for Ilo, Redfish,
IPMI, and DRAC.

Co-Authored-By: Jiri Tomasek <jtomasek@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Honza Pokorny <honza@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic5693506e67ca1a54ba88bdb4e6a02be0ebe4644

commit_message:
[WIP] - Check service_config_settings inheritance

Some services set the service_config_settings parameter, however
it's not inherited by the services/dockers that uses it as
base.

This patch check that the resources has the service_config_settings
are set on the base and whether is set on the dependant service/docker.

Change-Id: I90b3043c5e258a3b7dae1f5cf27ab587c188d561

commit_message:
[WIP] Build OVS system container

This commit add support for building openvswitch-vswitchd and openvswitch-db-server as system container.
As part of the patch, openvswitch-vswitchd and openvswitch-db-server Dockerfile is customized to copy
special files(config.json.template manifest.json service.template tmpfiles.template) for the system container
from a github repo to /exports/ directory.

Change-Id: I6ab1550c23f609b72ad32909748850f9031541b8

subject: Modify tech-debt policy
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 8042, 'name': 'Ji Strnsk', 'email': 'jistr@redhat.com', 'username': 'jistr'}, {'_account_id': 8532, 'name': 'Ryan Brady', 'email': 'rbrady@redhat.com', 'username': 'rbrady'}, {'_account_id': 10022, 'name': 'Gabriele Cerami', 'email': 'gcerami@redhat.com', 'username': 'panda'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-16 17:18:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-02-16 18:04:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

(8 comments)

Thanks for the proposal.  I feel that the proposed changes are a bit heavy for the TripleO project.  Perhaps we can find a middle ground considering that the existing (very lightweight) process hasn't been well adopted already.  I think it would be beneficial to work on actually getting consistent recognition of tech-debt during reviews than trying to force documentation of it with a complex process."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-02-16 18:42:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I am in agreement with Alex on basically every point.  This is far too much process overhead for something that's not ultimately that complex.

That said, I do think there would be value in providing guidance on what information should be provided to a tech-debt bug.  I would look for four pieces of information:

1) What did we do that is less than ideal?
2) Why didn't we do the ideal thing?
3) How might the less than ideal solution impact us going forward?
4) What effort would be required to do the ideal thing?

I believe that should be sufficient detail for anyone to make an informed decision on whether to address a piece of tech debt or continue carrying it."}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-16 23:49:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-17 00:21:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Alex Schultz wrote:

> (8 comments)
>
> Thanks for the proposal.  I feel that the proposed changes are a bit
> heavy for the TripleO project.  Perhaps we can find a middle ground
> considering that the existing (very lightweight) process hasn't been
> well adopted already.  I think it would be beneficial to work on
> actually getting consistent recognition of tech-debt during reviews
> than trying to force documentation of it with a complex process.

There are at least two things to consider here
1) the policy wasn't really well known. I made a quick poll, and very few people knew about its existence
2) the definition of technical debt was unclear, and it was unclear what impact they would have on the development, and why writing a bug about it would help anyone.

I agree the first step would be to help everyone recognize what is TD even before enforcing the policy.
We can add some code smells or best practice or pattern to recognize technical debt, but a good definition is also absolutely needed. I want to answer three questions here, in the order people would probably ask them

Why should I do all this ? Because it goes straight into your or some others future available time
once I found one what should I do ? Describe it so others can help you decide what to do with it.
What should I look at to find a TD ? look at the definition of TD, look at the comparison with a bug, look at the code smells and patterns we proposed"}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-02-17 00:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-17 00:39:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ben Nemec wrote:

> I am in agreement with Alex on basically every point.  This is far
> too much process overhead for something that's not ultimately that
> complex.

hold "complex'

> That said, I do think there would be value in providing guidance on
> what information should be provided to a tech-debt bug.  I would
> look for four pieces of information:
>
> 1) What did we do that is less than ideal? 2) Why didn't we do the
> ideal thing? 3) How might the less than ideal solution impact us
> going forward? 4) What effort would be required to do the ideal
> thing?

I think this matches the requirements I described for the initial description of the TD item, and I see opening a LP a bigger overhead than adding some text in a file in the code, especially if we don't find a way to classify the TD and just
reference a TD created to an existing TD class.
What would you do then to evaluate the tech debt and prioritize it that differs from what I described, and is less "complex" than what I described ?
A decision on the TD may need to be made eventually and communicated. In LP this may be just changing the status, in the register will be just to append a new line to the item.

People normally find a bug and append "it affects also me" and in the same way one may append the information of interests he had to pay on that debt.

I would anyway like to know what other code is using mine (the stack part), and maybe block it before the cost skyrockets.

I would really be interested in knowing the various steps in LP from the TD creation to the final decision, that is implement the TD register in LP, so we can really decide if LP is less overhead and will be enough for all the things we want to consider, or it may be easily be made enough by just adding some custom field to the bugs descriptions.

> I believe that should be sufficient detail for anyone to make an
> informed decision on whether to address a piece of tech debt or
> continue carrying it.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-02-17 01:01:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Alex Schultz wrote:
 > 
 > > (8 comments)
 > >
 > > Thanks for the proposal.  I feel that the proposed changes are a
 > bit
 > > heavy for the TripleO project.  Perhaps we can find a middle
 > ground
 > > considering that the existing (very lightweight) process hasn't
 > been
 > > well adopted already.  I think it would be beneficial to work on
 > > actually getting consistent recognition of tech-debt during
 > reviews
 > > than trying to force documentation of it with a complex process.
 > 
 > There are at least two things to consider here
 > 1) the policy wasn't really well known. I made a quick poll, and
 > very few people knew about its existence

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-August/121163.html

Was announced via the ML.  There was very little response so I don't know if people aren't following the ML or they don't care.  We do have very few policies so maybe we need to have a refresher every so often about the current ones.

 > 2) the definition of technical debt was unclear, and it was unclear
 > what impact they would have on the development, and why writing a
 > bug about it would help anyone.
 > 

It's about tracking it.  Previously we're doing it without actually tracking it anywhere so it was a push actually starting to document something.

 > I agree the first step would be to help everyone recognize what is
 > TD even before enforcing the policy.
 > We can add some code smells or best practice or pattern to
 > recognize technical debt, but a good definition is also absolutely
 > needed. I want to answer three questions here, in the order people
 > would probably ask them
 > 

I would rather spend time to improve automating checks around things we currently rely on people for. For example enforcing best practices, naming conventions, etc.  I think we currently hit those more often than suffering from tech-debt.

 > Why should I do all this ? Because it goes straight into your or
 > some others future available time
 > once I found one what should I do ? Describe it so others can help
 > you decide what to do with it.
 > What should I look at to find a TD ? look at the definition of TD,
 > look at the comparison with a bug, look at the code smells and
 > patterns we proposed"}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-17 04:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)

There's probably a lot to debate on, but I really want to at least clarify these points

- What to we want to do with tech debt informations

to then understand better

- What information we want to put in the tech debt reports.

After that we can also start again to argue

- How do we want people to put the tech debt report, and the result of what we decide to do with them

I think at this point it's clear we are going with the LP approach, and I'll analyse how to implement the register there."}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-17 04:38:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> It's about tracking it.  Previously we're doing it without actually
> tracking it anywhere so it was a push actually starting to document
> something.

That's fine. Now: track them to do what ?

> I would rather spend time to improve automating checks around things
> we currently rely on people for. For example enforcing best
> practices, naming conventions, etc.  I think we currently hit those
> more often than suffering from tech-debt.

How do you know we din't hit them if we didn't track them ? If I understood correctly it's not clear why to track them
and we don't even encourage finding them, since we prefer to make progress
on the project, than block on code issues."}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-02-19 10:22:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think this is a bit too heavy, and might result in spending too much time dealing with bureaucracy, but may not bring enough benefit over the current tracking method to justify the time spent.

But i like what Ben said about giving people guidance on what should (not "must" IMO) be described in a tech debt bug. I'd be +1 on such amendment of the policy.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-19 10:26:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-19 10:32:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-19 10:43:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-19 10:48:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-19 12:53:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Jiri Stransky wrote:

> I think this is a bit too heavy, and might result in spending too
> much time dealing with bureaucracy, but may not bring enough benefit
> over the current tracking method to justify the time spent.
>
> But i like what Ben said about giving people guidance on what should
> (not "must" IMO) be described in a tech debt bug. I'd be +1 on such
> amendment of the policy.

I realize I probably wrote the most heavy thing that could be done
This approach is something that we probably NEVER want to get to implement. But the general
idea seems to be appreciated. Let's draw some lines and understand what we can include
NOW in the modification.

First, I wanted to understand what do we want to do with a "good enough"
tech debt description.

Imagine someone writes a good tech debt bug, how do you act on it ? What are your 
next steps ? How do you make the suggestion worth the time ?

You write bug beause something is not working as it should. You or other people
are blocked, and you want to get attention for the issue, you want it to be solved
Other people see something is stuck, they may lend an hand, they somewhat feel
the importance.

You write tech debt bug because something is not coded as it should.
Who cares ? How do we convince people it's a good thing to raise the
issue on code and design weaknesses ? This is the most difficult part.
We don't do this: policy will probably get ignored, and doesn't probably make
sense to write one.

After we understand that, let's take another step back, what do we want people to write on a
tech debt bug that make it useful for what we decided to to with it ? What makes it "good" ?
That means make the writer and the solver times worth.

After we understand this, I think we are converging on writing the tech debts on launchpad, but
what fields do we need to add to manage the tech debg queue ?'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-19 13:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-02-19 13:20:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> First, I wanted to understand what do we want to do with a "good
 > enough"
 > tech debt description.
 > 
 > Imagine someone writes a good tech debt bug, how do you act on it ?
 > What are your
 > next steps ? How do you make the suggestion worth the time ?

We could perhaps go through the list at the beginning of the cycle and look at which ones might be worth addressing.

Also some items can be picked up organically. I just did this last week -- i realized that we didn't have a part of code DRY enough, and i wanted to add more non-DRY code, so i first sent 3 patches to refactor the existing approach, and 4th patch with my addition (just a few LOC now, after the refactoring).

I don't think this can be solved by more thorough tracking though, in my mind it's mostly about the approach to the problem. People might ignore LP bugs as well as in-tree YAML.

 > You write tech debt bug because something is not coded as it
 > should.
 > Who cares ? How do we convince people it's a good thing to raise
 > the
 > issue on code and design weaknesses ? This is the most difficult
 > part.
 > We don't do this: policy will probably get ignored, and doesn't
 > probably make
 > sense to write one.

Right :) It's also worth mentioning though that for some bugs and some tech debt, it's perfectly valid to leave it unaddressed, in the light of other issues that need attention.

 > 
 > After we understand that, let's take another step back, what do we
 > want people to write on a
 > tech debt bug that make it useful for what we decided to to with it
 > ? What makes it "good" ?
 > That means make the writer and the solver times worth.
 > 
 > After we understand this, I think we are converging on writing the
 > tech debts on launchpad, but
 > what fields do we need to add to manage the tech debg queue ?

+1 it makes sense to talk about this. From my point of view, the tech debt that really needs addressing will pop up at people from time to time. Maybe we could use the combination of "bug heat" feature of LP -- people subscribing to tech debt they consider important, and the priority field, and generally folks being vocal about what concerns they have about the quality, in what areas. Sometimes these things appear in code review (even when they're not 100% related to the patch), and that could spawn some follow up discussion. All this could give us some view of what might make sense to address. It's probably going to be more about people than tools, IMO.'}, {'account_id': 8532, 'date': '2018-02-19 13:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This is way to complicated and overbearing. Implementing this policy would severely decrease efficiency and either deter contributors or cause developers to reclassify their tech debt as bugs anyway to get around this process.

Add a "Tech Debt" tag to launchpad for bugs and follow the #FIXME pattern we have been using.'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-19 13:51:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ryan Brady wrote:

> This is way to complicated and overbearing. Implementing this policy
> would severely decrease efficiency and either deter contributors or
> cause developers to reclassify their tech debt as bugs anyway to get
> around this process.

Yes this is what has been discussed in the previous comments.

> Add a "Tech Debt" tag to launchpad for bugs and follow the #FIXME
> pattern we have been using.

Who have been using this pattern ? I've counted 31 tech-debt bugs in LP
since August. 15 had CRITICAL urgency and were solved., not sure how can a tech
debt be classified as CRITICAL. For ther rest it's
a bit confusing why they should be considered tech-debt, and to understand
what to do with them and when. Having a more precise definition and expectations
on the tech debt bug may help use it more often.'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-02-20 16:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-03-27 16:21:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-03-28 09:55:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-03-28 12:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-03-28 16:02:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

wow, I don't think I've ever seen a patch with 2x-2 in it."}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-04-03 16:12:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-12-29 13:47:56.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This patch has no activity for a while, per policy, we abandon it. Feel free to re-open if you think you're working on it."}]

commit_message:
Modify tech-debt policy

Modify tech-debt policy to expand its definitions, the consequences it
has to the development, and why it is so important to track technical
debt.
This change propose an alternative process for technical debts
management, where all the informations are put together to allow the
community to make them informed about the effective costs of contracted
technical debts.

Change-Id: Ibcbf7dc733e7a2e63644d38df2f530590c0627c4

commit_message:
Add alternative workflow to quickstart.sh

This change adds a new workflow to quickstart.sh that takes advantage of
the existing reproducer script.
THe reproducer role will be run and a null reproducer script will be
created, the run. The reproducer will have a generic configuration and
will not run on a specific change
The new path will be activated by --generate-reproducer option.

Depends-On: Ie21f47264680b468ce51a3e1f8305670889ccb41
Depends-On: Iecb7a30d0b4d83da9b33f50ad3becf66189666be
Change-Id: If5988021d661b40c7e15c8fc6c8b41f86e8043f5

this is a lot of parameters to add. Typically, we might suggest that one just use hieradata to do this by using the {{role.name}}ExtraConfig parameters. However, there is no specific rule or best practice about preferring parameters vs hieradata.

commit_message:
Extends audit serivce

Expose futher parameters as present in puppet-auditd module to allow
a more finer level of control over the audit service.

Change-Id: Ibd38c03d7ac4e1fb53c2a2fca096701b900c0156
Closes-Bug: #1668573

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17893, 'date': '2018-02-02 12:18:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

hi emanoel, did the actual script fail with this patch or this is what you experienced without the script? The reason I ask is that pip will use the http_proxy env if present (which is what this change carries out (apart from with yum which has `sudo` so it loses the user envs)?'}, {'account_id': 27768, 'date': '2018-02-02 15:30:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It actually did fail. I dont recall the failure right now but it was very early on, something like file not found. I read somewhere weeks back when I first applied the workaround that pip install does not always picks up the environment variable. So the recommended approach was to pass in the cmd line as a param'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-12-29 13:46:25.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This patch has no activity for a while, per policy, we abandon it. Feel free to re-open if you think you're working on it."}]

commit_message:
Featureset 22: run tempest (smoke+basic)

This commit will enable running tempest with a minimal/basic test
regex.  This is the same configuration that is run in rdophase2.
We should catch basic tempest smoke issues as part of tripleo promotion
not further down the production pipeline.

Change-Id: I704007e482e632297b93cb416e528abc722d39c6

'}, {'created': '2017-06-06 17:02:06.000000000', 'message': 'Add openstack undercloud restore

This new option allow to restore an Undercloud
backup.

If you want to try this new openstack undercloud option
in your dev env:

1- Copy the content of undercloud.py to:
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tripleoclient/v1/undercloud.py

2- Register the plugin in the entry points:
  Update: /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/python_tripleoclient-7.0xxx.devxxx-py2.7.egg-info/entry_points.txt
  Appending: undercloud_restore = tripleoclient.v1.undercloud:RestoreUndercloud      at the end of the file

You should be able to test the CLI then.

Change-Id: I0aa1086dc804fd03631e4bd4823e8613d58f9cc9
Related bp undercloud-backup-restore

commit_message:
Add openstack undercloud restore

This new option allow to restore an Undercloud
backup.

If you want to try this new openstack undercloud option
in your dev env:

1- Copy the content of undercloud.py to:
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tripleoclient/v1/undercloud.py

2- Register the plugin in the entry points:
  Update: /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/python_tripleoclient-7.0xxx.devxxx-py2.7.egg-info/entry_points.txt
  Appending: undercloud_restore = tripleoclient.v1.undercloud:RestoreUndercloud      at the end of the file

You should be able to test the CLI then.

Change-Id: I0aa1086dc804fd03631e4bd4823e8613d58f9cc9
Related bp undercloud-backup-restore

commit_message:
Enable ipmi_devintf kernel module

To allow ipmitool to locate the IPMI device ipmi_devintf
kernel module has to be loaded.

Closes-bug: #1745409
Change-Id: Id93720e2831f68ad27c4b88b387d119b8e995098

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-05-24 16:48:06.000000000', 'message': 'Add interactive prompt to recreate venv in case last run failed

The --clean option is problematic to default. I personally always
run with --clean, but we decided it was wrong to default to
deleting files from a user's home directory. This could be even
worse if a user set the working directory to something like "/"
by accident somehow.

However, if we do not clean the virtualenv we are not actually
including any new changes to the playbooks, roles or configs, since
they will not overwrite what we have from the previous runs.

In some cases, this can lead to quickstart failing, and all
subsequent runs will also fail for the same issue. That is a pretty
awful user experience if one is unfamiliar with the --clean option.

Instead, we can drop a dot file in the working dir to indicate the
run failed, so on the following run we can prompt the user to try
to recreate the virtualenv.

Change-Id: Iff29525a7558fd7991f60a6f2c044ece97e3aad8
'}, {'created': '2017-05-25 13:32:36.000000000', 'message': 'Add interactive prompt to recreate venv in case last run failed

The --clean option is problematic to default. I personally always
run with --clean, but we decided it was wrong to default to
deleting files from a user's home directory. This could be even
worse if a user set the working directory to something like "/"
by accident somehow.

However, if we do not clean the virtualenv we are not actually
including any new changes to the playbooks, roles or configs, since
they will not overwrite what we have from the previous runs.

In some cases, this can lead to quickstart failing, and all
subsequent runs will also fail for the same issue. That is a pretty
awful user experience if one is unfamiliar with the --clean option.

Instead, we can drop a dot file in the working dir to indicate the
run failed, so on the following run we can prompt the user to try
to recreate the virtualenv.

Change-Id: Iff29525a7558fd7991f60a6f2c044ece97e3aad8
'}]
commit_message:
Add interactive prompt to recreate venv in case last run failed

The --clean option is problematic to default. I personally always
run with --clean, but we decided it was wrong to default to
deleting files from a user's home directory. This could be even
worse if a user set the working directory to something like "/"
by accident somehow.

However, if we do not clean the virtualenv we are not actually
including any new changes to the playbooks, roles or configs, since
they will not overwrite what we have from the previous runs.

In some cases, this can lead to quickstart failing, and all
subsequent runs will also fail for the same issue. That is a pretty
awful user experience if one is unfamiliar with the --clean option.

Instead, we can drop a dot file in the working dir to indicate the
run failed, so on the following run we can prompt the user to try
to recreate the virtualenv.

Change-Id: Iff29525a7558fd7991f60a6f2c044ece97e3aad8

[{'created': '2017-08-30 08:08:08.000000000', 'message': "Adds support to configure 'ilo_port' for 'pxe_ilo' driver

Using Tripleo, one cannot not create a node with 'ilo_port' in
node's driver_info when 'pxe_ilo' driver is used.
Ironic driver 'pxe_ilo' driver supports configuring non-default
port to connect to iLO using 'ilo_port' as a node's driver_info
property. This commit adds that support.

Change-Id: I579d7fbce59cbe4af5f033d0a12095d4d2177c3b
Closes-Bug: #1713911
"}]
commit_message:
Adds support to configure 'ilo_port' for 'pxe_ilo' driver

Using Tripleo, one cannot not create a node with 'ilo_port' in
node's driver_info when 'pxe_ilo' driver is used.
Ironic driver 'pxe_ilo' driver supports configuring non-default
port to connect to iLO using 'ilo_port' as a node's driver_info
property. This commit adds that support.

Change-Id: I579d7fbce59cbe4af5f033d0a12095d4d2177c3b
Closes-Bug: #1713911

Why are these different than the roles directory? The roles directory has each one as a list entry. This allows for concatenation, then parsing the yaml. Without that, it makes it more difficult to process.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2017-12-06 17:16:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Why are these different than the roles directory? The roles directory has each one as a list entry. This allows for concatenation, then parsing the yaml. Without that, it makes it more difficult to process.

I'll change it to arrays. Originally when listing available roles was implemented using action it was oposite problem [1]. I'll update it to make it consistent with roles directory.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/509832/4/tripleo_common/actions/plan.py@226"}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2017-12-06 17:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2018-01-03 23:24:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 7065, 'date': '2018-01-22 17:20:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8532, 'date': '2018-01-23 14:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
[WIP] Add networks directory

This patch creates networks directory to hold networks definitions. This is initial
step in getting the networks operated the same way as Roles.

Change-Id: I79940d46192fc73847684eb27dff05812f9ef5d5

commit_message:
FFU: Remove all the old elements files

If some element file is not provided by deployment steps or rpm
than it's bug but not FFU one. We instead need to make sure old
elements are _really_ gone.

Change-Id: I93142ebc9564bb2cad0612069d58605a10c00b9e
Resolves: rhbz#1574258 rhbz#1561255

commit_message:
Revert "Revert "Change default endpoint map entries to use TLS""

This reverts commit d5b34858de524fbb56e674c1be6b2fd36167204f.

It also sets EnablePublicTLS as part of the default resource registry.
This way that value can be read by tripleo-common.

Depends-On: Ie50ca1ade3894d48f8d682a59a088d1a0fc8527c
Change-Id: I339a9af0a655e14f669dee8d382630844e9bc66f

commit_message:
TLS by default for the overcloud for VIPs and FQDNs

This gets a TLS certificate for the overcloud when necessary:

* If no incoming cert/key is provided and we don't expect the
  overcloud's certmonger instances to request the certificates,
  we request one to the undercloud's certmonger local CA.

* If a certificate was provided, we verify if it's user-provided
  or if it was autogenerated.

  - If it was user-provided we pass through that certificate

  - If it was autogenerated, we request or resubmit the request
    if it's needed.

* We also accept the EnableTLS flag, which the deployer can
  explicitly turn off if they decide not to use TLS.

* As an addition, it will add both the FQDN and the IP in the
  SAN of the certificate.

Change-Id: Ie50ca1ade3894d48f8d682a59a088d1a0fc8527c

commit_message:
Add OS_USERNAME and OS_PROJECT_NAME to PS1

This patch adds OS_USERNAME and OS_PROJECT_NAME to the PS1 of the
command prompt. The should help reduce confusion about which user
and project is being used to interact with the openstack.

Change-Id: I58269cc00a3c66199acba3c432e9844ad83d3832

Ceph jewel creates the client.bootstrap-osd auth entry when the cluster

auth will already be populated on the monitors and the OSD nodes will

commit_message:
Unnessary deploying of bootstrap-osd ceph auth entry

Ceph jewel creates the client.bootstrap-osd auth entry when the cluster
is created. heat does not need to pass this key to ceph::key as the
auth will already be populated on the monitors and the OSD nodes will
extract a copy from memory. This patch removes client.bootstrap-osd from
the ceph::profile::params::client_keys array.

Change-Id: Ia9c50afd3a88b27e6e0dca2ce150f91633681466
Partial-bug: 1769722
Depends-on: I11f134bed59da706a03ce4a70d941145c16f8175

commit_message:
Keep plan-environment only on upgrade

To avoid passing all the deploy options (nodes count, flavor
ntp & so on ..) we need to keep *only* the plan-environment file
for update/upgrade and FFU.

Change-Id: Ia34cbf36b240f540841822fddd8d9d192c48493f

commit_message:
Set FixedIp by default for public-facing VIP

For new deployments, this sets the *FixedIPs parameter in order to get a
predictable VIP. We'll then use this predictable VIP to set it as a SAN
for the TLS certificate in order to have TLS by default.

For the case where we'ere using network-isolation, we look for the
external network. If we're not using network isolation, we use the
ctlplane network. For both cases, we base IP on the allocation range,
also taking into account if there are already IPs allocated in that
range (which is usually the case for the ctlplane network).

Co-Authored-By: Cdric Jeanneret <cjeanner@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I40ce7d88897c6eb6c6cae95d377d72b3a7249772

commit_message:
[WIP] Update tripleo-inventory for extra nodes on OVB

Supplemental nodes may not be either provisioned via the libvirt/setup
role (virt) or through OVB by way of the 'extra' node deployment(cite).

This patch updates the tripleo-inventory role to allow for the OVB
workflow.

Change-Id: I04175b216f38082074d4de1e0c1a4c3177b3e7ec
